image.altText: Half underwater half sunset

items.synopsis: Climate scientists say natural "anaesthetics" have been masking the true impact of climate change for years but have now worn off. Here's why the world's ocean temperatures are at record highs and what they could bring.

title.children: With the world's oceans in the middle of an unprecedented heatwave, scientists are worried

image.altText: Meditation session on a grassy clearing in bushland.

items.synopsis: A festival company which ran events promoted as "empowering women" is being pursued by workers who say they have not been paid and attendees who say the three-day "The Gathering of The Goddesses" was far from what was advertised.

title.children: 'Gathering of the Goddesses' event organiser being pursued by disgruntled patrons, artists

image.altText: Mon Lulan looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Men's sheds have become important community spaces, but for some women who want to learn practical home maintenance skills, it is not an environment they feel comfortable in.

title.children: 'Work with the men's shed': Mon faces challenges with trying to set up a 'she shed'

image.altText: A man sitting on a bench looks ahead at the sunset with a neutral expression. He's wearing an Australian Rules jersey.

items.synopsis: No professional male AFL player, past or present, has ever publicly come out as gay or bisexual. Insiders say a culture of homophobia lingers.

title.children: Michael's an out gay man who plays Aussie rules. Why isn't there anyone like him in the AFL?

image.altText: A man in a dark shirt in an office

items.synopsis: A former executive at one of the country's most disastrous share market floats in years says he wasn't surprised when the share price crashed, wiping billions of dollars from the fortunes of investors, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: 'Stuck with the rancid bacon': Insider lifts lid on the share market disaster that cost investors billions

image.altText: Olga Carmona smiles with her World Cup winner's medal around her neck

items.synopsis: Just hours after a player-of-the-match performance in the Women's World Cup final, Spain captain Olga Carmona found out her father had died.

title.children: Spain World Cup hero Olga Carmona learns of father's death after final victory

image.altText: A team of soccer players wearing red and blue celebrates after winning a competition

items.synopsis: While they made history on Sunday night, Spain's first Women's World Cup title will always be haunted by the players who weren't there.

title.children: Spain's World Cup win lays bare the progress and problems of women's football

image.altText: Tameka Yallop (blurry in the foreground) carries her daughter as she waves to an applauding crowd at the FIFA Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: It's normal to feel some symptoms of football withdrawal after the Matildas' run and the joy of the Women's World Cup in Australia and New Zealand. So, here's how to keep riding that train.

title.children: How to keep getting your Matildas fix after the Women's World Cup

image.altText: A fire burns over a hill. It is night,  and the sky is black with the fire and smoke red and orange.

items.synopsis: A parks and wildlife director says a planned fire that got through containment lines to encroach on Alice Springs was fuelled by an introduced species of grass that is in the region "to stay".

title.children: 'Not ideal' as nearly half of outback national park goes up in flames

image.altText: Woman in mask shopping in Woolworths packaged food aisle June 28

items.synopsis: Every day the impact of the cost-of-living crisis means we are paying more for most things. So what is the cost of living and how is it measured?

title.children: You don't have to be an economist to know Australia is in a cost-of-living crisis. But what can be done?

image.altText: Profile, close up of a bird of prey with speckled chest feathers.

items.synopsis: Breeding peregrine falcons can suffer when rock climbers climb the cliffs they nest upon because it results in unattended chicks, but specialist Adam Hardy praises those people who do the right thing by avoiding certain cliffs for periods of the year.

title.children: Rock climbers and peregrine falcons are attracted to the same cliffs. Here's how they co-exist

image.altText: A man standing among piles of rubbish in the bush.

items.synopsis: Piles of rubbish have been left in bushland on the NSW Central Coast after those living there were moved on.

title.children: Former homeless camp resembles 'landfill' near coast town's CBD

image.altText: man in yellow shirt and backpack

items.synopsis: Adil Abbas is the second food delivery worker to die in Sydney in the past month, prompting calls for reform of NSW's road rules.

title.children: 'We have to bury his dreams': Family mourn 19yo student killed while delivering food in Sydney

image.altText: Ash covered volcano crater with ocean view in the background.

items.synopsis: Planning a trip this summer but don't want to travel far? Back Roads has got you covered.

title.children: Once known as the Pearl of the Pacific, Rabaul has everything to offer the intrepid traveller

image.altText: PM Albanese waves to labor conference

items.synopsis: For a political party that makes a virtue of having its fights in the open, Labor's national conference didn't involve a whole lot of fighting. But that doesn't mean there aren't battles on the horizon, writes Tom Lowrey.

title.children: Albo 2032? What Labor's conference tells us about what a long-term Albanese government might look like

image.altText: Tayla Cox wears pink and holds her baby girl Murphy

items.synopsis: The bodies of Tayla Black and her daughter, Murphy Margaret were found by police in their Rockhampton home two weeks ago. Ms Black’s husband, Matthew Cox was charged with their murders.

title.children: 'A tragedy for everyone': Man accused of murdering his wife and 11-week-old baby faces court

image.altText: Damien Hardwick stands holding a footy while wearing a Gold Coast Suns polo

items.synopsis: Damien Hardwick signs a six-year deal to coach the Gold Coast Suns months after stepping away from Richmond, where he led the Tigers to three premierships.

title.children: Suns complete Hardwick coup as triple-premiership coach joins Gold Coast

image.altText: An office building with the AGL logo showing, with a backdrop of other sky-high office buildings on a grey day.

items.synopsis: Westpac and BlueScope post their earnings at the start of another reporting-season week, AGL is set to keep Loy Yang open until mid-2035, and Qantas is hit with a class action. Follow live.

title.children: AGL to keep Loy Yang power station operational until 2035, Qantas hit with class action, ASX slips

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket has continued to slip throughout the morning and into the early afternoon, down 0.2% to 7,136 points as of 1pm AEST. (Remember for live figures, head to the top of the blog and expand the pinned post and scroll down for the full quote list). The slip is thanks to investors being disappointed by China's policymakers and its smaller-than-expected lending rate cuts (more on that in a moment). It is a mixed bag across the sectors — consumer non-cyclicals are down 0.9%, health care has dropped 0.6%, and financials and basic materials are down 0.3% each. For the academic and educational sector, it's gained 1.4% — the most out of any sector today — while consumer cyclicals are up 1.1% and energy has gained 0.7%. As for the top five movers so far today: Breville Group +14% Premier Investments +13% Lovisa Holdings +6.8% NIB Holdings +6.6% Paladin Energy +5.8% And the bottom five movers for the day: Iress -29.4% A2 Milk Company -11.7% Reliance Worldwide -8.85 Elders -7.4% Vicinity Centres -3.4%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX continues to slip as China rates decision disappoints investors

children.content: The Australian sharemarket has continued to slip throughout the morning and into the early afternoon, down
0.2% to 7,136 points
as of 1pm AEST.
(Remember for live figures, head to the top of the blog and expand the pinned post and scroll down for the full quote list).
The slip is thanks to investors being disappointed by China's policymakers and its smaller-than-expected lending rate cuts (more on that in a moment).
It is a mixed bag across the sectors —
consumer non-cyclicals are down 0.9%
health care has dropped 0.6%
, and
financials and basic materials are down 0.3% each
For the
academic and educational sector, it's gained 1.4%
— the most out of any sector today — while
consumer cyclicals are up 1.1%
and
energy has gained 0.7%
As for the top five movers so far today:
Breville Group +14%
Premier Investments +13%
Lovisa Holdings +6.8%
NIB Holdings +6.6%
Paladin Energy +5.8%
And the bottom five movers for the day:
Iress -29.4%
A2 Milk Company -11.7%
Reliance Worldwide -8.85
Elders -7.4%
Vicinity Centres -3.4%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: AGL Energy has struck a deal with the Victorian government to keep its Loy Yang coal power station running until mid-2035 to provide Victorians with "a higher level of certainty". AGL signed the structured transition agreement which will allow the company to coordinate the retirement of the station — which is Victoria's largest electricity generator — with the state government. Last September, AGL brought forward the closure of Loy Yang by a decade to 2035, after buckling to the pressure placed on them by investors and lenders. The deal also allows for the closure of the coal-fired plant earlier than scheduled, provided it's not needed for "the reliable and secure supply of electricity in Victoria", as long as it was given the green light by the Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AGL to keep Loy Yang open until 2035

children.content: AGL Energy has struck a deal with the Victorian government to keep its
Loy Yang coal power station running until mid-2035
to provide Victorians with "a higher level of certainty".

AGL signed the structured transition agreement which will allow the company to coordinate the retirement of the station — which is Victoria's largest electricity generator — with the state government.
Last September, AGL brought
forward the closure of Loy Yang by a decade to 2035
, after buckling to the pressure placed on them by investors and lenders.
The deal also
allows for the closure of the coal-fired plant earlier than scheduled
, provided it's not needed for "the reliable and secure supply of electricity in Victoria", as long as it was given the green light by the Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: BlueScope Steel, the largest steelmaker in Australia, has reported a smaller profit in the last financial year compared to the one prior, down 64% to $1.01 billion. BlueScope's earnings before interest and tax fell by 59 per cent to $537 million. "Operating cash flow for the half year, after capital expenditure, was $1.34 billion," CEO Mark Vassella said. "The balance sheet remains strong with $703 million net cash, positioning the group well in a period of increased capital spending on projects that underpin sustainable earnings and growth." In its report to the ASX, BlueScope also divulged that its board had approved a $1.15 billion "comprehensive reline and upgrade" at one of its blast furnaces at its Port Kembla steelworks, which it expects to be finalised by mid-to-late 2026 — two years before Port Kembla's steelworks turn 100. BlueScope chair John Bevan described the results as "robust" despite the "changing macroeconomic environment" of the last financial year. BlueScope will pay a dividend of 25 cents per share.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BlueScope profit falls by 64pc, commits to Port Kembla upgrade

children.content: BlueScope Steel
, the largest steelmaker in Australia, has reported a smaller profit in the last financial year compared to the one prior, down 64% to $1.01 billion.
BlueScope's earnings before interest and tax fell by
59 per cent to $537 million
"Operating cash flow for the half year, after capital expenditure, was $1.34 billion," CEO Mark Vassella said.
"The balance sheet remains strong with $703 million net cash, positioning the group well in a period of increased capital spending on projects that underpin sustainable earnings and growth."
In its report to the ASX, BlueScope also divulged that its board had approved a
$1.15 billion "comprehensive reline and upgrade" at one of its blast furnaces at its Port Kembla
steelworks, which it expects to be finalised by
mid-to-late 2026
— two years before Port Kembla's steelworks turn 100.
BlueScope chair John Bevan described the results as "robust" despite the "changing macroeconomic environment" of the last financial year.
BlueScope will pay a dividend of 25 cents per share.

image.altText: A family of four with cows behind them.
